Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of mystery, suspicion and seclusion towards local community for anonymity and security reasons, whilst the Dutch seem to positively patrol their own streets looking for trouble. Both approaches must be irritating but I'd bet with sufficient time in both areas, a kind of self-adaptation 'bliss point' could be reached

While credited as a Tom and Jerry cartoon, this is not the cat-and-mouse team but an earlier Mutt-and-Jeff rip-off featuring them going about to survive their everyday lives, like most other animals do, or that their problems nearly always seem to solve themselves. The premise, however funny, fails to attract the necessary interest. The timing of the punch lines makes for rather boring viewing, thus cut short. Not a disaster on the scale of "LoveCare"

What is left of Planet Earth is populated by a few poor and starving rag-tag survivors. They must eat bugs and insects, or whatever they can find. The wealthy sharecropping owners (authentic hats, for sure!) secure sustenance at the expense of the poor, forcing brilliant inventor George Holly to dish out justice by himself. 'The League of Loving Hearts', a group of masked vigilantes travels the affected areas, administering medical care and hope.

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is clearly a throwback to the 80's Ninja craze era. Well, it is an enjoyable one and if you're a fan of 80's ninja movies, it is probably one of biggest you can get.
